repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body: This wraps properties/pickle/dataclasses functions inside a suitable critical section, so that they can't corrupt the interpreter state.

comment_data.body: Refactored slightly so we only read from `self` instead of re-reading all the members.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2316,14 +2326,18 @@ def %(unpickle_func_name)s(__pyx_type, long __pyx_checksum, __pyx_state):
                 def __reduce_cython__(self):
                     cdef tuple state
                     cdef object _dict
-                    cdef bint use_setstate
-                    state = (%(members)s)
-                    _dict = getattr(self, '__dict__', None)
+                    cdef bint use_setstate = False
+                    with CRITICAL_SECTION(self):
+                        _dict = getattr(self, '__dict__', None)
+                        state = (%(members)s)
                     if _dict is not None:
                         state += (_dict,)
                         use_setstate = True
                     else:
-                        use_setstate = %(any_notnone_members)s

comment_data.body: Why is the `critical_section_placeholder_name` different from the other placeholders?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -104,10 +104,11 @@ class TemplateCode:
     """
     _placeholder_count = 0
 
-    def __init__(self, writer=None, placeholders=None, extra_stats=None):
+    def __init__(self, writer=None, placeholders=None, extra_stats=None, critical_section_placeholder_name=None):

comment_data.body: It's unfortunate that we don't have a good way of running transforms _after_ applying the substitutions. But it seems an easy change to build a pipeline that includes the substitutions as a regular pipeline step. Then we could just write `pipeline=[Normalise…(), Substitute…(), Interpret…(), Analyse…()]`, which looks much cleaner to me than running the transforms manually.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2337,9 +2348,12 @@ def __setstate_cython__(self, __pyx_state):
                     'checksum': checksums[0],
                     'members': ', '.join('self.%s' % v for v in all_members_names) + (',' if len(all_members_names) == 1 else ''),
                     # Even better, we could check PyType_IS_GC.
-                    'any_notnone_members' : ' or '.join(['self.%s is not None' % e.name for e in all_members if e.type.is_pyobject] or ['False']),
+                    'pyobject_indices' : repr(tuple(n for n, e in enumerate(all_members) if e.type.is_pyobject )),
                 },
-                level='c_class', pipeline=[NormalizeTree(None)]).substitute({})
+                level='c_class', pipeline=[NormalizeTree(None)]).substitute(
+                    {'CRITICAL_SECTION': self._create_critical_section_name_node(node.scope, node.pos)
+                })
+            pickle_func = InterpretCompilerDirectives(None, {})(pickle_func)
             pickle_func.analyse_declarations(node.scope)

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
            # only one writer thread so no race between reader and writer
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,90 @@
+# mode: run
+
+cimport cython
+
+import threading
+import pickle
+
+cdef class C:
+    cdef public object o
+    cdef readonly int i
+
+def test_properties(n_writers, n_readers):
+    """
+    >>> test_properties(2, 2)
+    """
+
+    # Mostly just a "do the references get messed up?" stress test
+    c = C()
+    o1 = object()
+    o2 = object()
+    cdef object c_obj = c
+    cdef object two = eval("2")  # obfuscate from Cython a bit
+    
+    barrier = threading.Barrier(n_writers+n_readers)
+    done = threading.Event()
+
+    def writer():
+        barrier.wait()
+        while not done.is_set():
+            c_obj.o = o1
+            # Test documented interaction of locking with threadsafe properties
+            with cython.critical_section(c):
+                c.i += 1
+                c.i *= <int>two
+                if c.i > 1000:
+                    c.i = 0
+            c_obj.o = o2
+    
+    def reader():
+        barrier.wait()
+        for _ in range(5000):
+            p = pickle.dumps(c_obj)
+            o = c_obj.o
+            assert c_obj.i % 2 == 0
+
+    readers = [ threading.Thread(target=reader) for _ in range(n_readers) ]
+    writers = [ threading.Thread(target=writer) for _ in range(n_writers) ]
+
+    for thread in readers+writers:
+        thread.start()
+    for thread in readers:
+        thread.join()
+    done.set()
+    for thread in writers:
+        thread.join()
+
+@cython.dataclasses.dataclass(order=True)
+cdef class DC:
+    x: object
+    y: object
+
+def test_dataclasses():
+    """
+    >>> test_dataclasses()
+    """
+    cdef object dc1 = DC(x=1.0, y=1.0)
+    cdef object dc2 = DC(x=2.0, y=2.0)
+
+    barrier = threading.Barrier(2)
+    done = threading.Event()
+
+    def writer():
+        barrier.wait()
+        while not done.is_set():
+            # only one writer thread so no raace between read and writer

comment_data.body: Why does this need a critical section? Is the access to `self.__class__` not otherwise guarded in any way?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -568,32 +587,33 @@ def generate_cmp_code(code, op, funcname, node, fields):
     names = [name for name, field in fields.items() if (field.compare.value and not field.is_initvar)]
 
     with code.indenter(f"def {funcname}(self, other):"):
-        code.add_code_chunk(f"""
-            if other.__class__ is not self.__class__: return NotImplemented
+        code.add_code_line(f"cdef {node.class_name} other_cast")
+        with code.indenter(f"with {code.critical_section_placeholder_name}(self, other):"):
+            code.add_code_chunk(f"""
+                if other.__class__ is not self.__class__: return NotImplemented

comment_data.body:
A further idea: Instead of requiring an exact list of pipeline steps, we could also allow a small set of feature flags, e.g. `with_cython_directives`, and then construct a corresponding pipeline list internally. But that seems worth a separate interface than the `TreeFragment` constructor. Either just a separate function, or something more fancy using the Builder pattern, e.g.
```python
parse_tree = TreeFragmentParserBuilder().substitute().interpret_directives().analyse_declarations()
tree = parse_tree(fragment_code_string, substitute=placeholders)
```
Not something to implement in this PR, though - it would certainly benefit from some more thinking.

+                    'pyobject_indices' : repr(tuple(n for n, e in enumerate(all_members) if e.type.is_pyobject )),
                 },

comment_data.body:
Mostly just that it's shared between multiple functions while all the other placeholders just last for a single function so it's convenient to have a place to look it up.
With that said, there's no real need for it to be attached to the template so I'll remove that.

comment_data.body: Hmm. We don't know what user code might use the critical section for (and what conflicts may arise). Probably not to guard attribute/property access though…

comment_data.body: I'm not sure if `getattr()` is something that is particularly well guarded by a critical section, but I guess that if it gets released for the lookup, it would get re-acquired after the access and for the subsequent member reads. I'm not sure that we can do better.
comment_data.diff_hunk:

             pickle_func = TreeFragment("""
                 def __reduce_cython__(self):
+                    cdef Py_ssize_t idx
                     cdef tuple state
                     cdef object _dict
-                    cdef bint use_setstate
-                    state = (%(members)s)
-                    _dict = getattr(self, '__dict__', None)
+                    cdef bint use_setstate = False
+                    with CRITICAL_SECTION(self):
+                        _dict = getattr(self, '__dict__', None)
+                        state = (%(members)s)

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
From Cython 3.3, Cython adds critical sections to automatically generated functions.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -147,6 +147,21 @@ Limited API).  Note that unlike the "raw" ``PyThread_type_lock`` our
 wrapping will avoid deadlocks with the GIL.
 
 
+Automatically applied critical sections
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+From Cython 3.2, Cython adds critical sections to automatically generated functions.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
The thread-safety here is achieved by adding ``with cython.critical_section(self[, other]):``
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -147,6 +147,21 @@ Limited API).  Note that unlike the "raw" ``PyThread_type_lock`` our
 wrapping will avoid deadlocks with the GIL.
 
 
+Automatically applied critical sections
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+From Cython 3.2, Cython adds critical sections to automatically generated functions.
+This includes properties on extension types (e.g. ``cdef public int x`` or
+``cdef readonly int x``), the auto-generated pickle functions of
+extension types, and functions of ``cython.dataclasses.dataclass`` class.
+The thread-safety here is achieve by adding ``with cython.critical_section(self[, other]):``

comment_data.body:
My view is:
* At very least this won't deadlock with user code (because critical sections ensure that)
* If user code is using critical sections on the same object to guard access to these attributes at Cython-level then it works well
* If they're using something else to guard access at Cython-level then it doesn't work well, but they really just need to write the properties themselves if they want it to be thread-safe.

comment_data.body: I've turned off auto-pickle here because it makes these tests very sensitive to exactly what the pickle code looks like

 ######## pkg/__init__.py ########
 
 ######## pkg/coverage_test_py.py ########
-# cython: linetrace=True
+# cython: linetrace=True, auto_pickle=False

commit.message: Add some pseudo-thread safety to properties and pickle
Implement for dataclasses too (still needs testing)
Revert a couple of stray changes

Apply suggestions from code review

Co-authored-by: scoder <stefan_ml@behnel.de>

commit.message:
Move type attribute access outside of critical section

Avoids a warning (and doesn't need to be guarded)

Turn off auto_pickle on coverage test

It makes it quite sensitive to the exact form of the pickled
function, and given that we don't actually pickle anything,
it should never show up on coverage.

title: Thread safety for generated code
